N, P co-doped Cu-based catalyst was synthesized by calcining activated carbon impregnated with diammonium hydrogen phosphate and impregnating active component copper. When the contents of N and P were 0.40% and 2.61% and the reaction temperature was 225 ℃, Cu/20NPAC catalyst had 90.4% acetylene conversion and 88.8% acetaldehyde selectivity, and notably, the catalytic performance remained basically unchanged within 20 h of reaction, which was superior than the Cu-based and Zn-based catalysts reported. The characterization results confirmed the excellent catalytic performance depended on the synergistic effect between N, P doped activated carbon and active component copper. TEM showed that the doped support could effectively improve the dispersion of active component copper and inhibit metal agglomeration. H2-TPR and XPS illustrated reduction of high valence copper were effectively inhibited in catalyst preparation and reaction. In addition, TPD showed an increased adsorption to acetylene. The high activity and stability of the catalyst showed that N, P co-doped support was an effective way to improve the catalytic performance of acetylene hydration. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Key Words Acetylene hydration N, P co-doped Cu-based catalyst Synergistic effect 1 Introduction Acetaldehyde (CH3CHO), as the starting chemical for the synthesis of many important industrial chemicals [1–4], is usually synthesized by ethylene direct oxidation and acetylene hydration [5]. The production route which uses acetylene hydration to acetaldehyde is still very attractive in China where abundant coal resources make acetylene obtainable at a low price [6]. It is found that transition metal ions with d10 electronic structure, such as Hg2+, Cd2+, Ag+, Au+, Zn2+ and Cu2+, have catalytic activity for acetylene hydration reaction [7–13]. However, the high toxicity of mercury- and cadmium-based catalysts seriously harm the ecological environment and human health [5, 14]. Ag+ is more readily reduced and causes catalyst deactivation [8]. Unfortunately, Zn-based catalysts often require high loading but poor stability [15]. Considering the economic cost and environmental protection factors, copper can serve as an active component to replace toxic and precious metals in the hydration of acetylene. On the basis of previous researches, the zeolite which is the traditional support of acetylene hydration catalyst is easy to accumulate carbon and deactivate [16]. In recent years, the research on Zn-based catalysts mainly focuses on the modification of the mesoporous materials MCM-41 [17, 18]. However, when the molecular sieve framework is exposed to water at high temperature, it will cause the collapse of the framework, resulting in the reduction of the active site and poor catalytic performance. Therefore, the development of effective support for acetylene hydration is especially significant. As one of the important catalyst supports, carbon-based materials are widely applied in many practical applications [19–21]. However, due to the single composition and structure of the original carbon and the lack of anchor sites of the active phase, the dispersion of metal nanoparticles on the carbon materials is uneven, which is further easy to aggregate and leach [22]. Heteroatom-doping (B, N, S, P) has greatly changed electronic properties and chemical activities of pristine carbons [23]. Among all the heteroatoms, N which has similar atomic size with C atom is widely investigated [24]. In nitrogen doped carbon materials, metal nanoparticles can nucleate and grow on nitrogen-containing groups, and metal nanoparticles acquire small nano size and narrow distribution, so as to adjust the activity of metal/N-doped carbon composites [25–27]. Nitrogen atoms will significantly affect the chemical state of the loaded metal through the interaction caused by electron transfer between metal nanoparticles and nitrogen doped supports [28, 29]. Phosphorus has the same valence electron number and similar chemical properties with nitrogen. Importantly, P is a promising carbon dopant with stronger n-type behavior and electron-donating ability than N [30]. Chen et al. [31] reported a novel highly porous nitrogen-phosphorus co-doped graphene sheet supported Pd catalyst for oxidation of 5‑hydroxymethylfurfural. Nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped graphene sheet was beneficial to increase the proportion of Pd2+ species on the surface, which was favorable for reducing the activation energy of reactant transformation and product formation. Lou et al. [32] designed a Pd/NP-Coal-CFs catalyst with excellent performance for formic acid oxidation reaction. The higher specific surface areas of nitrogen-phosphorus co-doped coal-based carbon fibers and interaction between nitrogen and phosphorus were beneficial to improve catalytic performance. Zhu et al. [33] reported iron atoms were uniformly scattered on the surface of nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped carbon hollow spheres successfully. It revealed that the O2-FeNxPy species were the active sites and the electron configuration of Fe center was changed by nitrogen-phosphorus co-doping which promoted the ORR process. Therefore, the catalytic activity will be optimized when carbon materials are doped with nitrogen and phosphorus. Previous studies showed that Zn-based and Cu-based catalysts had poor stability, and their catalytic activity decreased significantly after 8 h of reaction [34, 35]. Based on the influence of N, P co-doped carbon materials, we adopted a simple and effective method to prepare doped coconut shell activated carbon using diammonium hydrogen phosphate as nitrogen source and phosphorus source. Subsequently, an active compound of CuCl2 was introduced into the N, P co-doped AC support for gas phase acetylene hydration. By changing the amount of diammonium hydrogen phosphate and adopting a series of characterization, the effects of nitrogen and phosphorus doped activated carbon support on the structure and catalytic performance of the catalyst were systematically studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Raw materials The following materials were used in the study: 40–60 mesh coconut shell activated carbon (AC), CuCl2•2H2O (99%), (NH4)2HPO4 (99%), Na2HPO4•12H2O (99%), CH4N2O (99%), high purity water, C2H2 (98%). All of the materials were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation N, P co-doped supports were prepared by calcining activated carbon impregnated with diammonium hydrogen phosphate which are used as N source and P source. Firstly, 1 g diammonium hydrogen phosphate was evenly dissolved in 10 mL deionized water, and 5 g activated carbon was added and impregnated at room temperature for 24 h. Then, it was transferred to a drying overnight at 80 ℃. Finally, AC impregnated with diammonium hydrogen phosphate was calcined in a N2 atmosphere tube furnace at 700 ℃ following a heating rate of 5 ℃/min and a holding temperature of 2 h. When cooled to room temperature, the N, P co-doped activated carbon named 20NPAC was obtained (the weight of diammonium dihydrogen phosphate was 20% of the weight of activated carbon). Using the same method, the prepared N, P co-doped activated carbons with different loading amounts of diammonium hydrogen phosphate were named 5NPAC, 10NPAC, 30NPAC and 40NPAC, and the calcined activated carbons without doping N and P was named AC. N, P co-doped Cu-based catalysts were prepared by introducing active component Cu into the doped supports. 0.6196 g CuCl2•2H2O was dissolved in 10 mL deionized water, and 4 g xNPAC (x = 0, 5, 10, 20, 30, 40) was added after stirring evenly. The theoretical loading of copper was fixed at 5 wt%. These catalysts were impregnated and stirred for 24 h at room temperature and dried at 80 ℃ for 12 h. The prepared catalysts were named Cu/AC, Cu/5NPAC, Cu/10NPAC, Cu/20NPAC, Cu/30NPAC and Cu/40NPAC, respectively. Simultaneously, Cu/20NAC and Cu/20PAC catalysts were prepared using urea as nitrogen source and disodium hydrogen phosphate as phosphorus source. Similarly, the weight of urea and diamine hydrogen phosphate were 20% of the weight of activated carbon, and the theoretical load of Cu was fixed at 5 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The following characterization techniques were applied. The pore structure parameters were detected by N2 adsorption measurements using the Micromeritics ASAP 2020C instrument. The crystal phase structures were analyzed by German Brock D8 ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer (XRD). Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and acetylene temperature-programmed desorption (C2H2-TPD) experiments were performed using AutoChem 1 II 2920 instrument. The catalyst particle sizes and agglomerations were analyzed by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using JEOL JEM2010. The element compositions and chemical valence states on the surface were analyzed by Thermo ESCALAB250XI X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS). 2.4 Catalyst evaluation The performances of acetylene hydration reaction were tested in a fixed bed reactor with 2 mL of the catalysts. The volume of water was controlled by a peristaltic pump and the flow rate of acetylene was controlled by a mass flowmeter (C2H2 GHSV= 90 h − 1, and mole ratio n(H2O)/n(C2H2) = 4). Firstly, nitrogen was pumped into the reaction tube to remove impurities attached to the catalyst and residual gasses in the reactor. When the reactor was heated to 180 ℃, the catalyst was activated with water delivered by a peristaltic pump for 30 min. Then, the flow of acetylene and the amount of water were set to the desired value. Reaction products were taken at one hour interval and a gas chromatograph (GC-2014C) was selected to analyze the composition of the products. Acetylene conversion X and acetaldehyde selectivity S were used as evaluation indexes of catalyst performance, and the calculation formula are as follows: X = Φ A 0 − Φ A Φ A O × 100 % S = Φ A A 1 − Φ A × 100 % Among them, ΦA0 is the initial total volume fraction of acetylene, ΦA is the volume fraction of residual acetylene, ΦAA is the volume fraction of acetaldehyde in the product, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of fresh Cu/xNPAC catalysts The structure and chemical properties of fresh Cu/xNPAC catalysts are researched in detail to determine the influence of the N, P co-doped on catalyst natures. As shown in Fig. 1 , the elemental scanning results of fresh Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC show that Cu, N and P are successfully loaded on the supports. In order to determine the specific content of elements in the catalysts, the element analysis of the fresh catalysts is carried out, and the results are shown in Table 1 . The contents of Cu in Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts measured by ICP are 4.76% and 4.89% respectively, which is consistent with the theoretical value of 5%. The contents of P in AC and 20NPAC are 0.07% and 2.61%. The content of N in AC and 20NPAC measured by elemental analyzer is 0.4% and 0.79%. It can be concluded that, compared with Cu/AC catalyst, the P and N contents of Cu/20NPAC catalyst are increased by 2.54 wt% and 0.39 wt% respectively after the modification of activated carbon with diammonium hydrogen phosphate. The different doping amounts of N and P also confirm why TEM scanning shows that the content of P element in Cu/20NPAC catalyst increases significantly, while the content of N element has almost no significant difference. For investigating the effects of doped support and loaded active components on catalyst structures, we study the structural parameters of fresh AC, 20NPAC and Cu/xNPAC catalysts by N2 adsorption desorption method. The result in Fig. 2 a shows that the adsorption capacity of all catalysts increases sharply at the relative pressure P/P0 of 0.001, and shows an obvious hysteresis loop between 0.48–1.0, which is shown as the type IV adsorption isotherm of mesoporous materials. The pore size distribution in Fig. 2b also shows that all catalysts have mesoporous structure. It illustrates that the mesoporous structure is still maintained after heteroatom doping and active component loading, and the skeleton structure of the AC supports are not damaged. The pore structure parameters of fresh AC, 20NPAC, and Cu/xNPAC catalysts are shown in Table 2 . The loading of active component Cu and the introduction of nitrogen and phosphorus heteroatoms into AC result that pore diameter is increased and the surface area and pore volume are reduced compared with pure activated carbon. This indicates that the N and P groups and metal particles will block partial small pore structures, resulting in larger pores and smaller specific surface area and pore volume [36]. It is worthwhile to note that the variation trend of catalytic activity (Fig. 3 a and 3b) is not followed that of specific surface area of catalysts, which is convenient to research the influence of other factors on catalytic activity except the pore structures of catalysts. Fig. 2c shows the XRD figures of the fresh AC, Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts. In all catalysts, the only detected width diffraction peaks at 24.4° and 43.7° correspond to the (002) and (101) planes of AC support [37]. At the same time, there are no characteristic peaks related to copper in Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts, inferring that Cu particles are less than the detection limit of XRD or exist in amorphous form. Fig. 2d shows the H2-TPR of the fresh Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts. It indicates that both Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC have three reduction peaks, which correspond to the reduction of Cu2+, Cu+ and oxygen-containing functional groups, respectively [38, 39]. The reduction peak of Cu2+ in Cu/20NPAC catalyst appears at 392 ℃, while that in Cu/AC catalyst appears at 344 ℃, which indicates the reduction peak of Cu2+ in Cu/20NPAC catalyst shows an increase of 48 ℃ for that in Cu/AC catalyst. In the same way, the reduction peak of Cu+ in Cu/20NPAC catalyst shows an increase of 54 ℃ for that in Cu/AC catalyst. The increased Cu reduction peak may suggest the existence of the strong interaction between Cu and 20NPAC support [40]. Meanwhile, the significantly increased desorption peak area of Cu2+ and Cu+ in Cu/20NPAC catalyst also indicates that the N, P co-doped active carbon can effectively inhibit the reduction of high valent copper. 3.2 The catalytic performance of catalysts We study the catalytic performance of 20NPAC support and Cu-based catalysts prepared by different copper salt (CuCl, Cu (NO3)2, CuCl2, CuSO4) for acetylene hydration reaction in Fig. S1. The catalytic performance of 20NPAC is basically negligible. The acetylene conversion and acetaldehyde selectivity are greatly improved when different copper salts are introduced on 20NPAC support, and the order of catalytic performance of different copper salts is CuCl2 > CuSO4 > Cu (NO3)2 > CuCl. These results show that the active components may be Cu2+ and Cu+, and chloride ions may facilitate the reaction but they are not required. Therefore, CuCl2 is selected as the copper source for acetylene hydration. Fig. 3a and 3b show the catalytic performance of Cu/xNPAC with different amount of diammonium hydrogen phosphate and 20NPAC at a reaction temperature of 210 ℃. The catalytic activity and stability of Cu/AC catalyst are poor in the acetylene hydration. After 10 h of reaction, the acetaldehyde selectivity continuously decreases by 19.1% from 30.3% to 11.2%. However, the catalytic performances of doped Cu/xNPAC catalysts are greatly improved. The catalytic performance increase with the amount of diammonium hydrogen phosphate, while the best performance of the catalysts is found that the amount of diammonium hydrogen phosphate is 20% of that of activated carbon. The Cu/20NPAC catalyst shows an excellent initial performance with 85.9% acetaldehyde selectivity, and the catalytic performance remains unchanged within 10 h. The catalytic performance of 20NPAC is only 10% acetaldehyde selectivity. These experimental data show that N, P co-doped Cu-based catalysts can improve the catalytic performance in acetylene hydration significantly and the significant catalytic performance in Cu/20NPAC catalyst depends on the synergistic effect of Cu and doped 20NPAC rather than the sum of the catalytic performance of Cu/AC and 20NPAC. When the reaction temperature is 210 ℃, the error bar analysis (Fig. 3c and 3d) of Cu-based catalysts with different amounts of diammonium hydrogen phosphate is analyzed to ensure the repeatability and reliability of the experiment. In order to further explore the effects of N doped and P doped catalyst on the catalytic performance, the catalytic performance test results of Cu/20NAC and Cu/20PAC at 225 ℃ are shown in Fig. 3e and 3f (The investigation of reaction temperature is shown in Fig. S2 of the supporting information). Compared with Cu/AC, the catalytic performance of Cu/20NAC and Cu/20PAC are improved, indicating that only nitrogen-doped or phosphorus-doped catalysts can also improve the catalytic performance. However, under the identical rection conditions, the acetaldehyde selectivity of Cu/20NAC catalyst is increased by about 70% in comparing with Cu/AC, while the aldehyde selectivity of the Cu/20NAC and Cu/20PAC catalysts are only 5% and 25% higher. Cu/20NPAC has excellent aldehyde selectivity and stability than Cu/20NAC and Cu/20PAC. These results indicate that Cu-based catalysts can exhibit excellent catalytic performance only when nitrogen and phosphorus are doped together. 3.3 Investigations of stability In order to explore the stability of Cu-based catalyst under optimal reaction conditions, the catalytic performance within 20 h is investigated in acetylene hydration in Fig. 4 . Cu/AC has poor acetylene conversion, acetaldehyde selectivity and stability. The conversion decreased by 28%, and the acetaldehyde selectivity decreased sharply from 30.2% to 2.5%. Obviously, N and P doped activated carbon improves effectively the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalyst in acetylene hydration. Acetylene conversion decreases from 90.4% to 89.4%, which decreases by 1.4% and acetaldehyde selectivity reduces by 4.1% from 88.8% to 84.7%. The stability of Cu/20NPAC catalysts is higher than that of Cu-based and Zn-based catalysts reported for acetylene hydration [34, 35]. These results confirm that N, P co-doped activated carbon can effectively improve the catalytic performance of Cu-based catalyst. 3.4 Adsorption properties of C2H2 Fig. 5 shows the diagram of acetylene desorption of fresh and used 20NPAC, Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts at 50 - 700 ℃. An obvious acetylene desorption peak is detected at about 150 ℃. Similar desorption temperature indicates that the adsorption intensity of acetylene will not change after N and P co-doped AC. The order of desorption peak area is Cu/20NPAC > Cu/AC >20NPAC, which is same as the change trend of catalytic performance. At the same time, the order of the desorption peak area of the used catalysts is the same as that of fresh catalysts. This shows that the order of acetylene adsorption by the used catalysts has not changed. It can be seen that N, P co-doped catalysts can improve the acetylene hydration performance of Cu-based catalysts by increasing the adsorption capacity of reactant acetylene [41, 42]. 3.5 Surface chemical properties of Cu-based catalysts XPS and XAES detect the surface compositions and chemical states on the surface of catalysts Fig. 6 a displays that Cu 2p,O 1s,C 1 s and Cl 2p are detected in Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC. While, N 1 s and P 2p are only present in Cu/20NPAC. The high-resolution XPS C 1 s scan (Fig. 6b) shows that 20NPAC consists primarily of sp2-hybridized carbon (284.9 eV), along with some C-P (284.1 eV), CN (285.8 eV) and CO moieties (286.8 eV). The high resolution XPS N 1 s (Fig. 6c) shows that the primary type of N species is pyrrole nitrogen (400.2 eV) which has a relative content of 68.9% (Table S1), along with pyridine nitrogen (398.3 eV) and graphite nitrogen (401.9 eV) [43]. The high resolution XPS P 2p (Fig. 6d) show the two types of P species in 20NPAC, P-C (132.7 eV) and P-O (133.6 eV), respectively [44]. These data show that nitrogen and phosphorus are successfully doped on the supports. The chemical states of copper on the fresh and used catalysts are analyzed in Fig. 7 . In Fig. 7a and 7b, the main peak around 935.1 eV and 933.0 eV are attributed to Cu2+ and (Cu++ Cu0), respectively [45, 46]. The XAES spectra which distinguishes between Cu+and Cu0 are shown in Fig. 7c and 7d. The peak at 918.6 eV is owed to Cu0, the peak at 915.5 eV is owed to Cu2+ and Cu+ [47], while the peak at 910.5 eV is attributed a transition state [48]. Cu contents in different valence states are obtained by calculating the corresponding deconvolution peak area, which is listed in Table 3 . The proportions of Cu2+ and Cu0 in the fresh Cu/20NPAC are 54.5% and 9.2%, while that in fresh Cu/AC are 34.5% and 17.1%. The presence of Cu0 in the catalyst may be due to the reduction by AC during the preparation of catalyst [49, 50]. In fresh Cu/20NPAC, the proportion of Cu2+ is higher and the proportion of Cu0 is lower than that in Cu/AC catalyst. Similarly, the used Cu/20NPAC catalyst has a higher proportion of Cu2+and a lower proportion of Cu0. These dates show that the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 can be inhibited partially through the electronic effects between copper and doped supports during catalyst preparation and reaction process, and maintain Cu with higher chemical valence, which has same conclusion with the results of H2-TPR. In addition, the proportion (Cu2++Cu+)/Cu0 in Cu/20NPAC is larger than that in Cu/AC. Combined with performance test results, it is proved that the higher content of high valence copper is more conducive to improve the catalytic performance and the reduction of high valence Cu to Cu0 will lead to catalyst deactivation, which is consistent with the results reported in the previous literature [8, 51, 52]. Therefore, the XPS results show that the N, P co-doped support is beneficial to inhibit the reduction of high-valent copper, thereby effectively improving the catalytic performance. 3.6 TEM and XRD analysis In order to demonstrate the morphology and agglomeration of Cu-based catalysts, TEM characterization and particle size analysis are shown in Fig. 8 . The TEM images shows that there are different degrees of agglomeration in fresh and used Cu-based catalysts. After statistical analysis of a certain number of small particle metals in the catalyst, it is found that the average particle size of fresh Cu/AC catalyst (Fig. 8a) is 10.6 nm, while that of fresh Cu/20NPAC (Fig. 8c) is only 1.83 nm. The results illustrate that N, P doped activated carbon can increase the dispersion of active components and inhibit the metal agglomeration in the process of catalyst preparation, which have a positive impact on the catalytic performance in acetylene hydration. Unfortunately, for the used catalysts after 10 h, Cu/20NPAC (Fig. 8d) also show metal agglomeration, with an average particle size of 6.80 nm, which shows that N, P doped activated carbon cannot effectively inhibit metal agglomeration in the reaction process. XRD is used to determine the change of metal state of catalysts after reaction and investigate the composition of metal phase after reduction, as shown in Fig. 9 . We observe the diffraction peak of Cu0 (PDF#99–0034) in the used Cu/AC and Cu/20NPAC catalysts, which shows that the Cu2+/Cu+ are reduced to Cu0 and metal agglomerate during the reaction process. It is worth noting that the diffraction peak intensity of Cu0 in Cu/20NPAC catalyst is significantly lower than that in Cu/AC catalyst, which shows that N and P doped activated carbon helps to partially inhibit the reduction of high valent copper in the reaction process, so as to improve the catalytic performance. TEM and XRD results show that N, P doped activated carbon can increase the dispersity of active components, inhibit metal agglomeration and effectively inhibit the reduction of high copper in the reaction process, thus effectively improving the catalytic performance of Cu/20NPAC catalyst. 4 Conclusion N, P co-doped AC supported copper catalysts were prepared by a simple calcination method for acetylene hydration. At the optimal reaction temperature, the Cu/20NPAC catalyst showed excellent catalytic performance compared with the Cu/AC catalyst. Within 20 h, the conversion of acetylene was maintained at about 90% and the selectivity of acetaldehyde decreased by about 4% from 88.8% to 84.7%. Acetaldehyde selectivity and stability were superior than these of the Cu-based and Zn-based catalysts reported. The excellent catalytic performance of Cu/20NPAC catalyst depended on the synergistic effect between N, P doped activated carbon and active component copper, which was conducive to promoting the dispersion of copper, inhibiting the reduction of Cu2+ and metal agglomeration in the catalyst preparation and reaction process, and increasing the adsorption of acetylene during the reaction. These results show that N, P co-doped activated carbon provides an important idea for the research of acetylene hydration reaction support, which provides a basis for the development of high-performance Cu-based acetylene hydration catalyst. coredata.dc:description: N, P co-doped Cu-based catalyst was synthesized by calcining activated carbon impregnated with diammonium hydrogen phosphate and impregnating active component copper. When the contents of N and P were 0.40% and 2.61% and the reaction temperature was 225 ℃, Cu/20NPAC catalyst had 90.4% acetylene conversion and 88.8% acetaldehyde selectivity, and notably, the catalytic performance remained basically unchanged within 20 h of reaction, which was superior than the Cu-based and Zn-based catalysts reported. The characterization results confirmed the excellent catalytic performance depended on the synergistic effect between N, P doped activated carbon and active component copper. TEM showed that the doped support could effectively improve the dispersion of active component copper and inhibit metal agglomeration. H2-TPR and XPS illustrated reduction of high valence copper were effectively inhibited in catalyst preparation and reaction. In addition, TPD showed an increased adsorption to acetylene. The high activity and stability of the catalyst showed that N, P co-doped support was an effective way to improve the catalytic performance of acetylene hydration.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of N, P co-doped activated carbon supported Cu-based catalyst for acetylene hydration
